content: Right-click on an empty spot on the toolbar and choose "Customize..." On the Mail tab, the available icons will show below, including "Write". The icon can be drag-and-dropped onto the sample toolbar. See the attached image.

content: More information about your Thunderbird installation is needed. What should we understand when you write "after an email update...."? Was it a Thunderbird update or just a download of new emails? How are your mail accounts set up? Using the POP or the IMAP protocol? Do do have a recent backup copy of your Thunderbird profile folder? Go to Account Settings > account name > Disk Space (or Synchronisation & Storage if IMAP) > and verify if ◉ "Don't delete any messages" is checked
creator: Mapenzi

content: Go to TB menu > Appearance > Message List and choose Table View.

Tierny.Bernard said
Update Thunderbird and import the Orange email contact file into Thunderbird. Thank you.

creator: sfhowes

content: Assuming this is an IMAP account, it is possible that the folders became unsubscribed. Thunderbird has no size limitations. If you are able to see the missing folders from another client, then resetting with Thunderbird should simply be to resubscribe. That global database just contains an index, but not the messages themselves. My suggestion: log onto your online account and verify that the folders are there. then, highlight account in folder pane, right-click and then select 'subscribe' and look for the folders.
creator: davidsk

content: Wenn ich jeden Unterordner einzeln aktiviere, dann funktioniert das "Abonnieren". Natürlich eine Schildbürgerarbeit bei gut 100 Unterordnern. Trotzdem vielen Dank.

content: error 550 5.7.1 is not specific, but usually means a policy violation. that is, the receiving provider may suspect spam. Your posted message states that the email provider is blocked, so that seems the appropriate direction to resolve this. contact your email provider. What you can do is to check your SMTP settings to ensure that you are using the appropriate authentication for the account.
creator: davidsk

content: If the Subscribe option is missing in TB, it suggests the account is POP, not IMAP. Check Server Type in Account Settings/Server Settings.

creator: davidsk

content: Thanks for the quick reply. I will assume that you are correct, even though for over 30 years, until now, I have been using 'move' with no problems. But what about all the emails I deleted, they are back also. Was there a problem with the latest update to Thunderbird, or did it make changes to the procedures that must be used that I was unaware of?
creator: hellnbak

content: I am not an IMAP guru, and a review would require detailed steps. No, thunderbird has not changed how IMAP is handled. All I know is that the steps I mentioned have been successful for capturing messages from an iMAP account to local folders and then removing from the server. Others may see this thread and have more in-depth feedback.
creator: davidsk

content: May I ask why you chose this two-step method instead of the 'move to' method? As I said, I have used the 'move to' method for over 30 years, with no problem until now. I'm an old fart (retired from the Air Force 37 years ago) and make no claims to being an expert on this or anything else, but to me this would seem to indicate that something has changed within the program. This is a disaster for me. I now have over 6,000 supposedly moved or deleted emails mixed throughout my inbox. And as I mentioned they are all grayed out like I had read them. But I cannot just attempt to delete all the greyed-out messages (assuming that somebody can shed some light on why my 'deleted' emails also came back) because there are also a good number of emails that I have read but did not attempt to move or delete them. I would not want to arbitrarily delete them also. I hope this is making sense. Please bear with me, I am battling the early stages of dementia (three active brain cells, and one of them is on life support)
creator: hellnbak

content: First, I encourage you to log onto your online account to see what is there. Second, I respond to questions on what will WORK. I am not the person to explain WHY something works or doesn't. What I will do is see if I can locate someone with more IMAP expertise. What I recommend is to list, in detail, your steps. You refer to messages being moved and deleted (two separate results) and also to ALL being restored. A detail list of the steps, clarifying what you did, may prove helpful. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: I apologize for throwing all this stuff at you. it's just that you are the only one that noticed me floating in my life boat. Sorry. And I really appreciate you trying to locate someone with more IMAP expertise. I'm not sure what you mean when you say that I should log onto my 'online account' to see what is there. All I know is that I click on the desktop Thunderbird icon and it takes me online to TB. Yeah, I are dum. As far as my steps, well, I sorted all my emails by Correspondents, then looked thru them to determine which ones I wanted to send to local folders and which ones I wanted to delete. I selected the ones to send to a local folder (clicked on the first one, held down shift and clicked on the last one) and if there were any within that batch that I didn't want to include I held down Ctrl and deselected them, then right clicked on the batch and selected 'Move to' and clicked on Local Folders, after which I selected and clicked on the folder I wanted. When I did this the selected emails disappeared from my inbox and the total number of emails decreased accordingly. As far as deleting emails, I used the method above to select the emails, then hit 'delete' on my keyboard. With the same results. When I opened TB this morning all of the deleted and moved emails had returned and the total had returned to the number of emails I had had prior to deleting and moving anything, grayed out but with a line thru them. When I stopped screaming and crying I decided to close and reopen TB, in the vain hope that everything would be as it should. BAD move, the deleted and moved emails were still there, still grayed out but no longer had a line thru them. If I had not restarted TB it would have simplified knowing which ones to delete (though probably trying to delete them again would not have worked any better the second time around). I did check a number of the local folders to see if they did contain the emails I tried to move there and as far as I could tell they had been moved there. Or more accurately, for whatever reason they were copied there. I hope this explains everything well enuf, if not please let me know what further information is needed.
creator: hellnbak

content:
Are you using a custom notification sound? Try a different one and see if that works.

A few versions ago, my custom sound stopped working, but only in Thunderbird - Windows would play it with no problem. The sound was one I made many years ago and had been working all along. It was a slightly unusual format - mono ADPCM. I remade it as a stereo PCM format file, and it worked again. It seemed that Thunderbird changed something that made it not able to use that format audio file. I never saw a confirmation of that, though.

This is all a long way of saying, try another file.
creator: rednoise

content: You might have to also check that notification sounds are enabled for TB in Windows Settings.
creator: sfhowes

content: I have no solution, but a suggestion: send a message to yourself to see if it comes back to your inbox. If it does, that is an indication that the message is being rejected at the receiving site. That could be perception of spam, blacklist, or other issues - but not issues that relate to the Thunderbird client.
creator: davidsk

content: If your sent messages appear in the Sent folder, they have been relayed by your provider's server to the recipients' servers. If they aren't received by your recipients, that is not a TB issue. The recipients should check their Spam/Junk folders and unblock your address if your mail is filtered to those folders.
creator: sfhowes
